elements.content: <ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">A new cobalt coordination polymer based on N-(Phosphonomethyl)imino-diacetic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PMIDA) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC) ligands, [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>(PMIDA)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(BTC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>]·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, has been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions, and characterized by elemental analysis, FT-IR spectroscopy, thermal analysis, and single crystal X-ray diffraction. The structure of the complex features a cubic 3D open framework constructed by [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>(PMIDA)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>] cluster and BTC ligand. The magnetic properties of this compound were also investigated.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new cobalt coordination polymer based on N-(Phosphonomethyl)imino-diacetic acid (H4PMIDA) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate acid (H3BTC) ligands, [Co15(PMIDA)6(BTC)2(H2O)12]⋅6H2O, has been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions, and characterized by elemental analysis, FT-IR spectroscopy, thermal analysis, and single crystal X-ray diffraction. The structure of the complex features a cubic 3D open framework constructed by [Co15(PMIDA)6(H2O)12] cluster and BTC ligand. The magnetic properties of this compound were also investigated.

elements.content:

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A new cobalt coordination polymer based on N-(Phosphonomethyl)imino-diacetic acid (H4PMIDA) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate acid (H3BTC) ligands has been synthesized, which features a cubic 3D open framework constructed by [Co15(PMIDA)6(H2O)12] cluster and BTC ligand.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">► A new cobalt coordination polymer,[Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>(PMIDA)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(BTC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>]·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, has been synthesized. ► Its structure features a cubic 3D open framework constructed by [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>(PMIDA)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>] cluster and BTC ligand. ► The magnetic properties of this complex were investigated.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

► A new cobalt coordination polymer,[Co15(PMIDA)6(BTC)2(H2O)12]⋅6H2O, has been synthesized. ► Its structure features a cubic 3D open framework constructed by [Co15(PMIDA)6(H2O)12] cluster and BTC ligand. ► The magnetic properties of this complex were investigated.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The investigation of the assembly of porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted much interest due to their structural diversity and promising applications for ion exchange, gas storage, separation, and catalysis. Many MOFs are constructed from preformed secondary building units, which are typically a few metal atoms grouped into a cluster that is chelated by carboxylic groups in carboxylic acid []. But very little progress has been made in using large clusters formed by phosphonic acid as building blocks for the hierarchical assembly of MOFs []. In recent years, the direct use of two types of organic acid ligands, such as a phosphonic acid and a carboxylic acid, has been found to be another effective method for the exploration of MOFs. In 2005, Mao et al.  reported the hydrothermal reactions of the lanthanide chlorides with MeN(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H)(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) (or Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) and sodium oxalate leading to seven new lanthanide oxalate phosphonate hybrids with three types of 3D network structures. In 2006, Mao et al.  further synthesized a 3D network complex of [La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ox)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>L)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O with tunnels running along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis by using the (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>L) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> as the co-ligands. In 2009, Sevov et al.  synthesized a complex of [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(cis-H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>E)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>]·12H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O by using the N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>COOH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L) and C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(COOH)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> (H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>E) as the co-ligands, which feature as 3D open-framework constructed by Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> clusters and cis-H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>E ligands. However, such investigation is still limited, and it still remains a great challenge for the exploration of MOFs with the use of phosphonic acid and a carboxylic acid as the co-ligands. Herein, we report the synthesis and crystal structure of a new cobalt coordination polymer based on N-(Phosphonomethyl)imino-diacetic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PMIDA) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC) ligands, [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>(PMIDA)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(BTC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>]·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), which has a cubic 3D open framework constructed by [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>(PMIDA)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>] clusters and BTC ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The investigation of the assembly of porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted much interest due to their structural diversity and promising applications for ion exchange, gas storage, separation, and catalysis. Many MOFs are constructed from preformed secondary building units, which are typically a few metal atoms grouped into a cluster that is chelated by carboxylic groups in carboxylic acid []. But very little progress has been made in using large clusters formed by phosphonic acid as building blocks for the hierarchical assembly of MOFs []. In recent years, the direct use of two types of organic acid ligands, such as a phosphonic acid and a carboxylic acid, has been found to be another effective method for the exploration of MOFs. In 2005, Mao et al.  reported the hydrothermal reactions of the lanthanide chlorides with MeN(CH2CO2H)(CH2PO3H2) (or Me2NCH2PO3H2) and sodium oxalate leading to seven new lanthanide oxalate phosphonate hybrids with three types of 3D network structures. In 2006, Mao et al.  further synthesized a 3D network complex of [La2(ox)2(H6L)]⋅2H2O with tunnels running along the a-axis by using the (H2O3PCH2)2NCH2CH2CH2CH2N(CH2PO3H2)2 (H8L) and H2C2O4 as the co-ligands. In 2009, Sevov et al.  synthesized a complex of [Co15L6(cis-H3E)2(H2O)18]⋅12H2O by using the N(CH2COOH)2(CH2PO3H2) (H4L) and C6H6(COOH)6 (H6E) as the co-ligands, which feature as 3D open-framework constructed by Co15L6 clusters and cis-H3E ligands. However, such investigation is still limited, and it still remains a great challenge for the exploration of MOFs with the use of phosphonic acid and a carboxylic acid as the co-ligands. Herein, we report the synthesis and crystal structure of a new cobalt coordination polymer based on N-(Phosphonomethyl)imino-diacetic acid (H4PMIDA) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate acid (H3BTC) ligands, [Co15(PMIDA)6(BTC)2(H2O)12]⋅6H2O (1), which has a cubic 3D open framework constructed by [Co15(PMIDA)6(H2O)12] clusters and BTC ligands.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">The hydrothermal reaction of Co(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O with H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PMIDA resulted in crystals with two different morphologies, cubes and hexagonal prisms . The latter crystals were identified by single-crystal X-ray diffraction as Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, which has been reported . The former complex is a new compound reported here.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The hydrothermal reaction of Co(CH3COO)2⋅4H2O with H3BTC and H4PMIDA resulted in crystals with two different morphologies, cubes and hexagonal prisms . The latter crystals were identified by single-crystal X-ray diffraction as Co2[O3PCH2N(CH2COO)2(H2O)5]⋅H2O, which has been reported . The former complex is a new compound reported here.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">X-ray analyses  reveal that the compound (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) contains fifteen cobalt(II) ions, six PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands, two BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands, and twelve aqua ligands as well as six lattice water molecules per formula unit. There are four crystallographically independent cobalt atoms in each asymmetric unit, which exhibit regular distribution as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>. The outer Co1 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by one phosphonate oxygen atom (O9), two carboxylic oxygen atoms (O3,O5) from three PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands as the monodentate forms, two carboxylic oxygen atoms (O1, O2) from one BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand as the chelate form (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>), and one coordinated water molecule (O1w). The second outer Co2 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by one nitrogen atom (N1A), three carboxylic oxygen atoms(O4,O4A,O5A) from three PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands and two phosphonate oxygen atoms (O7C,O9A) from two PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands, in which the N1A, O4A, O5A and O7C come from the same one PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand. The central Co3 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by six phosphonate oxygen atoms (O7, O7A, O7B, O7C, O7D, O7E) from six PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands as the monodentate forms. The outer Co4 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by three phosphonate oxygen atoms (O8, O8A, O8B) from three PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands as the monodentate forms and three coordinated water molecules. The Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond lengths are in the range of 2.045(3)–2.215(3) Å, and the Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond length is 2.185(3) Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: X-ray analyses  reveal that the compound (1) contains fifteen cobalt(II) ions, six PMIDA4- ligands, two BTC3- ligands, and twelve aqua ligands as well as six lattice water molecules per formula unit. There are four crystallographically independent cobalt atoms in each asymmetric unit, which exhibit regular distribution as shown in  . The outer Co1 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by one phosphonate oxygen atom (O9), two carboxylic oxygen atoms (O3,O5) from three PMIDA4- ligands as the monodentate forms, two carboxylic oxygen atoms (O1, O2) from one BTC3- ligand as the chelate form ( ), and one coordinated water molecule (O1w). The second outer Co2 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by one nitrogen atom (N1A), three carboxylic oxygen atoms(O4,O4A,O5A) from three PMIDA4- ligands and two phosphonate oxygen atoms (O7C,O9A) from two PMIDA4- ligands, in which the N1A, O4A, O5A and O7C come from the same one PMIDA4- ligand. The central Co3 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by six phosphonate oxygen atoms (O7, O7A, O7B, O7C, O7D, O7E) from six PMIDA4- ligands as the monodentate forms. The outer Co4 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by three phosphonate oxygen atoms (O8, O8A, O8B) from three PMIDA4- ligands as the monodentate forms and three coordinated water molecules. The CoO bond lengths are in the range of 2.045(3)-2.215(3) Å, and the CoN bond length is 2.185(3) Å.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">As shown in , each PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand in the compound coordinates to eight Co atoms, with the phosphonate group adopting a μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> bridging mode, the two carboxylate groups exhibiting μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> and μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> modes respectively, and the N atom only exhibiting μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> mode.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in , each PMIDA4- ligand in the compound coordinates to eight Co atoms, with the phosphonate group adopting a μ5-η2:η2:η1 bridging mode, the two carboxylate groups exhibiting μ2-η2:η0 and μ3-η2:η1 modes respectively, and the N atom only exhibiting μ1 mode.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The interconnection of the fifteen Co(II) ions by six PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> bridging ligands resulted in a bulbiform fifteen nuclear cluster unit, [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>(PMIDA)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>]. Each [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>(PMIDA)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>] cluster is connected to six BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands by coordinating deprotonated carboxylic group O atoms to six Co1 atoms as the chelate form, and each BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand is connected to three [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>(PMIDA)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>] clusters by coordinating deprotonated carboxylic group O atoms to Co1 atoms from three different clusters. The alternate connectivity between the [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>(PMIDA)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>] clusters and the BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands through their Co1<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bonds as the chelate forms leads to the 3D open-framework with two different kinds of channel tropisms along the a, b and c axes, respectively, in which the lattice water molecules are located (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). Taking the Co15 clusters and the BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands as 6-connecting nodes and 3-connecting nodes, respectively, the 3D network can be viewed as a 3,6-conneced binodal net. The Schläfli notation is (6<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The interconnection of the fifteen Co(II) ions by six PMIDA4- bridging ligands resulted in a bulbiform fifteen nuclear cluster unit, [Co15(PMIDA)6(H2O)12]. Each [Co15(PMIDA)6(H2O)12] cluster is connected to six BTC3- ligands by coordinating deprotonated carboxylic group O atoms to six Co1 atoms as the chelate form, and each BTC3- ligand is connected to three [Co15(PMIDA)6(H2O)12] clusters by coordinating deprotonated carboxylic group O atoms to Co1 atoms from three different clusters. The alternate connectivity between the [Co15(PMIDA)6(H2O)12] clusters and the BTC3- ligands through their Co1O bonds as the chelate forms leads to the 3D open-framework with two different kinds of channel tropisms along the a, b and c axes, respectively, in which the lattice water molecules are located ( ). Taking the Co15 clusters and the BTC3- ligands as 6-connecting nodes and 3-connecting nodes, respectively, the 3D network can be viewed as a 3,6-conneced binodal net. The Schläfli notation is (612 ⋅83)(63)2.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Moreover, there exist weak inner molecular hydrogen bonds among the coordinated water molecules (O1W and O2W) and adjacent carboxylic group O atoms (O2 and O6), with O⋯O distances in the range of 2.756(5)–3.005(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>Å. There also exist weak hydrogen bonds between the lattice water molecules (O3W) and the coordinated water molecules (O2W), with the O⋯O distances being 2.923(7) Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Moreover, there exist weak inner molecular hydrogen bonds among the coordinated water molecules (O1W and O2W) and adjacent carboxylic group O atoms (O2 and O6), with O⋯O distances in the range of 2.756(5)-3.005(5)Å. There also exist weak hydrogen bonds between the lattice water molecules (O3W) and the coordinated water molecules (O2W), with the O⋯O distances being 2.923(7) Å.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is related to that of [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(cis-H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>E)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>]·12H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in the literature , in which they have a similar Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> cluster unit and they all have 3D open-framework, but there are some differences between them in crystal structures. The known [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(cis-H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>E)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>]·12H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O compound belongs to the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/c, in which each Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> cluster is connected to six cis-H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>E ligands using the three deprotonated carboxylic groups at positions 1, 2, and 4 to coordinate via one of the O atoms to peripheral Co atoms (Co3, Co4 and Co6) as the monodentate forms, forming a 3D structure with the larger channels along the b and c axes. While the present compound crystallizes in cubic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>a-3, in which each [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>(PMIDA)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>] cluster is connected to six BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands by coordinating deprotonated carboxylic group O atoms to six Co1 atoms as the chelate forms, forming a 3D structure with the same channels along the a, b and c axes. Obviously, the present Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> cluster has higher symmetry than the reported Co15 cluster, and there is triple anti-axis, with four crystallographically independent Co(II) (while with eight crystallographically independent Co(II) in the reported Co15 cluster). In addition, the Co3 atom is the symmetry center of Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> cluster. The structural differences between the two compounds with similar Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> cluster unit can be attributed to the different carboxylic ligands used, namely from the flexible C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(COOH)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> to the rigid H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structure of compound 1 is related to that of [Co15L6(cis-H3E)2(H2O)18]⋅12H2O in the literature , in which they have a similar Co15L6 cluster unit and they all have 3D open-framework, but there are some differences between them in crystal structures. The known [Co15L6(cis-H3E)2(H2O)18]⋅12H2O compound belongs to the monoclinic space group C2/c, in which each Co15L6 cluster is connected to six cis-H3E ligands using the three deprotonated carboxylic groups at positions 1, 2, and 4 to coordinate via one of the O atoms to peripheral Co atoms (Co3, Co4 and Co6) as the monodentate forms, forming a 3D structure with the larger channels along the b and c axes. While the present compound crystallizes in cubic space group Pa-3, in which each [Co15(PMIDA)6(H2O)12] cluster is connected to six BTC3- ligands by coordinating deprotonated carboxylic group O atoms to six Co1 atoms as the chelate forms, forming a 3D structure with the same channels along the a, b and c axes. Obviously, the present Co15L6 cluster has higher symmetry than the reported Co15 cluster, and there is triple anti-axis, with four crystallographically independent Co(II) (while with eight crystallographically independent Co(II) in the reported Co15 cluster). In addition, the Co3 atom is the symmetry center of Co15L6 cluster. The structural differences between the two compounds with similar Co15L6 cluster unit can be attributed to the different carboxylic ligands used, namely from the flexible C6H6(COOH)6 to the rigid H3BTC.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">TGA curve (Fig. S1) shows that the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has three step weight loss between 70 and 1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The first weight loss is 11.10% occurring from 70 to 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which corresponds to the loss of 18 water molecules and can be compared with calculated value of 10.95%. The following two steps occurring from 300 to 1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C correspond to the decomposition of the ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: TGA curve (Fig. S1) shows that the compound 1 has three step weight loss between 70 and 1000°C. The first weight loss is 11.10% occurring from 70 to 300°C, which corresponds to the loss of 18 water molecules and can be compared with calculated value of 10.95%. The following two steps occurring from 300 to 1000°C correspond to the decomposition of the ligands.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">The magnetic susceptibilities (<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>) of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were measured under 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe in the 1.8–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K range (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). In the high temperature range, the two compounds show similar magnetic behaviors. The <ce:italic>χT</ce:italic> values at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K are 42.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>emu<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, and this value is in the normal range for octahedral Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> with an unquenched orbital momentum. As the temperature is lowered, the <ce:italic>χT</ce:italic> values first decrease slowly to round minima of 32.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>emu<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> at 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, then rises rapidly until 1.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (<ce:italic>χT</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>emu<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>). The data above 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K follows the Curie–Weiss law with <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>44.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>emu<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>13.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (see supporting information, Fig S2).This features suggest an overall antiferromagnetic (AFM) coupling between the Co(II) ions within the Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf> cluster, while the behavior below 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K may be due to the ferrimagnetic-like interaction in the low temperature range. However, because of the rather complicated structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with many possible exchange interactions between Co(II) ions, any further rationalization or simulation of the magnetic properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is unavailable.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The magnetic susceptibilities (χ) of compound 1 were measured under 1kOe in the 1.8-300K range ( ). In the high temperature range, the two compounds show similar magnetic behaviors. The χT values at 300K are 42.3emumol-1 K, and this value is in the normal range for octahedral CoII with an unquenched orbital momentum. As the temperature is lowered, the χT values first decrease slowly to round minima of 32.3emuKmol-1 at 20K, then rises rapidly until 1.8K (χT =48emuKmol-1). The data above 50K follows the Curie-Weiss law with C =44.3emumol-1 K and θ =-13.5K (see supporting information, Fig S2).This features suggest an overall antiferromagnetic (AFM) coupling between the Co(II) ions within the Co15 cluster, while the behavior below 20K may be due to the ferrimagnetic-like interaction in the low temperature range. However, because of the rather complicated structure of 1 with many possible exchange interactions between Co(II) ions, any further rationalization or simulation of the magnetic properties of 1 is unavailable.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The isothermal magnetization at 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>. The magnetization in the high-field region increases slowly and linearly, and the value of 24.4 Nβ at 35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe is far from saturation. These are consistent with the overall AFM interactions of the Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf> cluster, and are similar to the magnetic behavior of the above-mentioned [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(cis-H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>E)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>]·12H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, with also an overall AFM interaction between the Co(II) ions within the Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf> cluster. However, no indications of long-range ordering or slow-relaxation can be found from the field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) magnetization measurements and the thermal ac measurements (see supporting information, Fig S3 and Fig S4).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The isothermal magnetization at 2K is shown in  . The magnetization in the high-field region increases slowly and linearly, and the value of 24.4 Nβ at 35kOe is far from saturation. These are consistent with the overall AFM interactions of the Co15 cluster, and are similar to the magnetic behavior of the above-mentioned [Co15L6(cis-H3E)2(H2O)18]⋅12H2O, with also an overall AFM interaction between the Co(II) ions within the Co15 cluster. However, no indications of long-range ordering or slow-relaxation can be found from the field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) magnetization measurements and the thermal ac measurements (see supporting information, Fig S3 and Fig S4).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In summary, we have successfully synthesized a new MOF constructed by [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>(PMIDA)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>] cluster and BTC ligand by adjusting the ligand from the flexible to the rigid one. The magnetic property of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was also investigated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have successfully synthesized a new MOF constructed by [Co15(PMIDA)6(H2O)12] cluster and BTC ligand by adjusting the ligand from the flexible to the rigid one. The magnetic property of 1 was also investigated.

</ce:para><ce:section-title>Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Supplementary data to this article can be found online at <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2011.11.002" xlink:type="simple">doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2011.11.002</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para><ce:simple-para id="sp0055" view="all">A mixture of Co(Ac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (374<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1.50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PMIDA (136<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC (84<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was stirred in air for 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The resulting solution was heated in a stainless steel reactor with Teflon liner at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days. After a period of approximately 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h cooling to room temperature, two kinds of purple crystals with different shapes, cubes and hexagonal prisms, were isolated manually from pink gel, washed with water, and air-dried. Anal. Found (calcd, wt.%) for cubes: C, 19.53(19.47); H, 2.65(2.66); N, 2.71(2.84). IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>): 3437(vs), 1641(s), 1599(m), 1460 (m), 1402(s), 1022(s), 963(m).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Supplementary material

    Supplementary material 1.        Supplementary material 2.     

Supplementary material

Supplementary data to this article can be found online at doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2011.11.002.

A mixture of Co(Ac)2⋅4H2O (374mg, 1.50mmol), H4PMIDA (136mg, 0.6mmol), H3BTC (84mg, 0.4mmol), and 6mL of H2O was stirred in air for 0.5h. The resulting solution was heated in a stainless steel reactor with Teflon liner at 100°C for 2days. After a period of approximately 24h cooling to room temperature, two kinds of purple crystals with different shapes, cubes and hexagonal prisms, were isolated manually from pink gel, washed with water, and air-dried. Anal. Found (calcd, wt.%) for cubes: C, 19.53(19.47); H, 2.65(2.66); N, 2.71(2.84). IR (KBr, cm-1): 3437(vs), 1641(s), 1599(m), 1460 (m), 1402(s), 1022(s), 963(m).

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para id="sp0060" view="all">Crystal data for [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>(PMIDA)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(BTC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>]·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O: M<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2960.94, cubic, space group P a-3, a<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>20.8713(2) Å, β<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>90.00° V<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>9091.77(9) Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, Z<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>12, Dc<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2.163<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.0389, <ce:italic>wR</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.0967, GOF<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1.088. Data collection on CrysAlisPro, Oxford Diffraction Ltd., Version 1.171.34.36 CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo–Ka radiation (λ<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). All absorption corrections were performed using SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> by full-matrix least squares analysis with SHELXL-97 software. CCDC No. 797926.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Crystal data for [Co15(PMIDA)6(BTC)2(H2O)12]⋅6H2O: M=2960.94, cubic, space group P a-3, a=20.8713(2) Å, β=90.00° V=9091.77(9) Å3, Z=12, Dc=2.163gcm-3, R 1 =0.0389, wR 2 =0.0967, GOF=1.088. Data collection on CrysAlisPro, Oxford Diffraction Ltd., Version 1.171.34.36 CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Ka radiation (λ=0.71073Å). All absorption corrections were performed using SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least squares analysis with SHELXL-97 software. CCDC No. 797926.

Supplementary material

    Supplementary material 1.        Supplementary material 2.     

Supplementary material

Supplementary data to this article can be found online at doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2011.11.002.

A mixture of Co(Ac)2⋅4H2O (374mg, 1.50mmol), H4PMIDA (136mg, 0.6mmol), H3BTC (84mg, 0.4mmol), and 6mL of H2O was stirred in air for 0.5h. The resulting solution was heated in a stainless steel reactor with Teflon liner at 100°C for 2days. After a period of approximately 24h cooling to room temperature, two kinds of purple crystals with different shapes, cubes and hexagonal prisms, were isolated manually from pink gel, washed with water, and air-dried. Anal. Found (calcd, wt.%) for cubes: C, 19.53(19.47); H, 2.65(2.66); N, 2.71(2.84). IR (KBr, cm-1): 3437(vs), 1641(s), 1599(m), 1460 (m), 1402(s), 1022(s), 963(m).

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">X-ray analyses  reveal that the compound (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) contains fifteen cobalt(II) ions, six PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands, two BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands, and twelve aqua ligands as well as six lattice water molecules per formula unit. There are four crystallographically independent cobalt atoms in each asymmetric unit, which exhibit regular distribution as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>. The outer Co1 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by one phosphonate oxygen atom (O9), two carboxylic oxygen atoms (O3,O5) from three PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands as the monodentate forms, two carboxylic oxygen atoms (O1, O2) from one BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand as the chelate form (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>), and one coordinated water molecule (O1w). The second outer Co2 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by one nitrogen atom (N1A), three carboxylic oxygen atoms(O4,O4A,O5A) from three PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands and two phosphonate oxygen atoms (O7C,O9A) from two PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands, in which the N1A, O4A, O5A and O7C come from the same one PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand. The central Co3 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by six phosphonate oxygen atoms (O7, O7A, O7B, O7C, O7D, O7E) from six PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands as the monodentate forms. The outer Co4 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by three phosphonate oxygen atoms (O8, O8A, O8B) from three PMIDA<ce:sup loc="post">4<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands as the monodentate forms and three coordinated water molecules. The Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond lengths are in the range of 2.045(3)–2.215(3) Å, and the Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond length is 2.185(3) Å.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">TGA curve (Fig. S1) shows that the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has three step weight loss between 70 and 1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The first weight loss is 11.10% occurring from 70 to 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which corresponds to the loss of 18 water molecules and can be compared with calculated value of 10.95%. The following two steps occurring from 300 to 1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C correspond to the decomposition of the ligands.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">The magnetic susceptibilities (<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>) of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were measured under 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe in the 1.8–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K range (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). In the high temperature range, the two compounds show similar magnetic behaviors. The <ce:italic>χT</ce:italic> values at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K are 42.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>emu<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, and this value is in the normal range for octahedral Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> with an unquenched orbital momentum. As the temperature is lowered, the <ce:italic>χT</ce:italic> values first decrease slowly to round minima of 32.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>emu<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> at 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, then rises rapidly until 1.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (<ce:italic>χT</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>emu<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>). The data above 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K follows the Curie–Weiss law with <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>44.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>emu<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>13.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (see supporting information, Fig S2).This features suggest an overall antiferromagnetic (AFM) coupling between the Co(II) ions within the Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf> cluster, while the behavior below 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K may be due to the ferrimagnetic-like interaction in the low temperature range. However, because of the rather complicated structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with many possible exchange interactions between Co(II) ions, any further rationalization or simulation of the magnetic properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is unavailable.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The isothermal magnetization at 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K is shown in

The magnetization in the high-field region increases slowly and linearly, and the value of 24.4 Nβ at 35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe is far from saturation. These are consistent with the overall AFM interactions of the Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf> cluster, and are similar to the magnetic behavior of the above-mentioned [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(cis-H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>E)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>]·12H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, with also an overall AFM interaction between the Co(II) ions within the Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf> cluster. However, no indications of long-range ordering or slow-relaxation can be found from the field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) magnetization measurements and the thermal ac measurements (see supporting information, Fig S3 and Fig S4).</ce:para><ce:simple-para id="sp0060" view="all">Crystal data for [Co<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>(PMIDA)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(BTC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>]·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O: M<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2960.94, cubic, space group P a-3, a<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>20.8713(2) Å, β<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>90.00° V<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>9091.77(9) Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, Z<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>12, Dc<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2.163<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.0389, <ce:italic>wR</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.0967, GOF<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1.088. Data collection on CrysAlisPro, Oxford Diffraction Ltd., Version 1.171.34.36 CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo–Ka radiation (λ<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). All absorption corrections were performed using SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> by full-matrix least squares analysis with SHELXL-97 software. CCDC No. 797926.</ce:simple-para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
X-ray analyses  reveal that the compound (1) contains fifteen cobalt(II) ions, six PMIDA4- ligands, two BTC3- ligands, and twelve aqua ligands as well as six lattice water molecules per formula unit. There are four crystallographically independent cobalt atoms in each asymmetric unit, which exhibit regular distribution as shown in  . The outer Co1 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by one phosphonate oxygen atom (O9), two carboxylic oxygen atoms (O3,O5) from three PMIDA4- ligands as the monodentate forms, two carboxylic oxygen atoms (O1, O2) from one BTC3- ligand as the chelate form ( ), and one coordinated water molecule (O1w). The second outer Co2 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by one nitrogen atom (N1A), three carboxylic oxygen atoms(O4,O4A,O5A) from three PMIDA4- ligands and two phosphonate oxygen atoms (O7C,O9A) from two PMIDA4- ligands, in which the N1A, O4A, O5A and O7C come from the same one PMIDA4- ligand. The central Co3 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by six phosphonate oxygen atoms (O7, O7A, O7B, O7C, O7D, O7E) from six PMIDA4- ligands as the monodentate forms. The outer Co4 atom is hexahedrally coordinated by three phosphonate oxygen atoms (O8, O8A, O8B) from three PMIDA4- ligands as the monodentate forms and three coordinated water molecules. The CoO bond lengths are in the range of 2.045(3)-2.215(3) Å, and the CoN bond length is 2.185(3) Å.

TGA curve (Fig. S1) shows that the compound 1 has three step weight loss between 70 and 1000°C. The first weight loss is 11.10% occurring from 70 to 300°C, which corresponds to the loss of 18 water molecules and can be compared with calculated value of 10.95%. The following two steps occurring from 300 to 1000°C correspond to the decomposition of the ligands.

The magnetic susceptibilities (χ) of compound 1 were measured under 1kOe in the 1.8-300K range ( ). In the high temperature range, the two compounds show similar magnetic behaviors. The χT values at 300K are 42.3emumol-1 K, and this value is in the normal range for octahedral CoII with an unquenched orbital momentum. As the temperature is lowered, the χT values first decrease slowly to round minima of 32.3emuKmol-1 at 20K, then rises rapidly until 1.8K (χT =48emuKmol-1). The data above 50K follows the Curie-Weiss law with C =44.3emumol-1 K and θ =-13.5K (see supporting information, Fig S2).This features suggest an overall antiferromagnetic (AFM) coupling between the Co(II) ions within the Co15 cluster, while the behavior below 20K may be due to the ferrimagnetic-like interaction in the low temperature range. However, because of the rather complicated structure of 1 with many possible exchange interactions between Co(II) ions, any further rationalization or simulation of the magnetic properties of 1 is unavailable.

The isothermal magnetization at 2K is shown in  . The magnetization in the high-field region increases slowly and linearly, and the value of 24.4 Nβ at 35kOe is far from saturation. These are consistent with the overall AFM interactions of the Co15 cluster, and are similar to the magnetic behavior of the above-mentioned [Co15L6(cis-H3E)2(H2O)18]⋅12H2O, with also an overall AFM interaction between the Co(II) ions within the Co15 cluster. However, no indications of long-range ordering or slow-relaxation can be found from the field-cooled (FC) and zero-field-cooled (ZFC) magnetization measurements and the thermal ac measurements (see supporting information, Fig S3 and Fig S4).

Crystal data for [Co15(PMIDA)6(BTC)2(H2O)12]⋅6H2O: M=2960.94, cubic, space group P a-3, a=20.8713(2) Å, β=90.00° V=9091.77(9) Å3, Z=12, Dc=2.163gcm-3, R 1 =0.0389, wR 2 =0.0967, GOF=1.088. Data collection on CrysAlisPro, Oxford Diffraction Ltd., Version 1.171.34.36 CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Ka radiation (λ=0.71073Å). All absorption corrections were performed using SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least squares analysis with SHELXL-97 software. CCDC No. 797926.
